Class Client

  • java.lang.Object
    • Client

  • public class Client
extends java.lang.Object
    This class is an initial work-in-progress prototype for a command line Tinee client. It has been hastily hacked together, as often the case in early exploratory coding, and is incomplete and buggy. However, it does compile and run, and some basic functionality, such as pushing and reading tines to and from an instance of Server, is working. Try it out!

    The arguments required to run a client correspond to the #set(String, String, int) method: a user name, and the host name and port number of a Tinee server.

    You can compile and run this client using NetBeans; e.g., right-click this file in the NetBeans editor and select "Run File". Note, to provide the above arguments, you should set up a run configuration for this class: -> "Set Project Configuration" -> "Customize..." -> "New...".

    Assuming compilation using NetBeans (etc.), you can also run Client from the command line; e.g., on Windows, run:

    • C:\...\tinee> java -cp build\classes Client userid localhost 8888

    You will be significantly reworking and extending this client: your aim is to meet the specification, and you have mostly free rein to do so. (That is as opposed to the base framework, which you are not permitted to modify, i.e., the packages sep.tinee.server, sep.tinee.server, sep.tinee.server and] sep.tinee.server.) The constraints on your client are:

    • You must retain a class named Client) as the frontend class for running your client, i.e., via its static main method.
    • The main method must accept the same arguments as currently, i.e., user name, host name and port number.
    • Your client must continue to accept user commands on the standard input stream (System.in), and output on the standard output stream (System.out).
    • Any other conditions specified by the assignment tasks.

    Tip: generate and read the JavaDoc API documentation for the provided base framework classes (if you're not already reading this there!). After importing the code project into NetBeans, right-click the project in the "Projects" window and select "Generate Javadoc". By default, the output is written to the dist/javadoc directory. You can directly read the comments in the code for the same information, but the generated JavaDoc is formatted more nicely as HTML with click-able links.

    See Also:
